member.name: T:BigNum.BigFloat
member.summary:
An arbitrary-precision floating-point class
Format: Each number is stored as an exponent (32-bit signed integer), and a mantissa (n-bit) BigInteger. The sign of the number is stored in the BigInteger
Applicability and Performance: This class is designed to be used for small extended precisions. It may not be safe (and certainly won't be fast) to use it with mixed-precision arguments. It does support, but will not be efficient for, numbers over around 2048 bits.
Notes: All conversions to and from strings are slow.
Conversions from simple integer types Int32, Int64, UInt32, UInt64 are performed using the appropriate constructor, and are relatively fast.
The class is written entirely in managed C# code, with not native or managed assembler. The use of native assembler would speed up the multiplication operations many times over, and therefore all higher-order operations too.

member.name: T:BigNum.BigFloat.SpecialValueType
member.summary:
Floats can have 4 special value types:
NaN: Not a number (cannot be changed using any operations) Infinity: Positive infinity. Some operations e.g. Arctan() allow this input. -Infinity: Negative infinity. Some operations allow this input. Zero

member.summary: Not a special value

member.summary: Zero

member.summary: Positive infinity

member.summary: Negative infinity

member.name: F:BigNum.BigFloat.SpecialValueType.NAN
member.summary: Not a number

member.summary:
This affects the ToString() method.
With Trim rounding, all insignificant zero digits are drip

member.summary: Trim non-significant zeros from ToString output after rounding

member.name: F:BigNum.BigFloat.RoundingModeType.EXACT
member.summary: Keep all non-significant zeroes in ToString output after rounding

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.#ctor(BigNum.BigFloat,BigNum.PrecisionSpec)
member.summary:
Copy Constructor - constructs a new BigFloat with the specified precision, copying the old one.
The value is rounded towards zero in the case where precision is decreased. The Round() function should be used beforehand if a correctly rounded result is required.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.#ctor(System.String,BigNum.PrecisionSpec)
member.summary: Constructs a BigFloat from a string

member.name: P:BigNum.BigFloat.Precision
member.summary:
Read-only property. Returns the precision specification of the mantissa.
Floating point numbers are represented as 2^exponent * mantissa, where the mantissa and exponent are integers. Note that the exponent in this class is always a 32-bit integer. The precision therefore specifies how many bits the mantissa will have.

member.name: P:BigNum.BigFloat.Sign
member.summary: Writable property: true iff the number is negative or in some cases zero (<0) false iff the number if positive or in some cases zero (>0)

member.name: P:BigNum.BigFloat.IsSpecialValue
member.summary: Read-only property. True if the number is NAN, INF_PLUS, INF_MINUS or ZERO False if the number has any other value.

member.name: P:BigNum.BigFloat.SpecialValue
member.summary:
Read-only property, returns the type of number this is. Special values include:
NONE - a regular number ZERO - zero NAN - Not a Number (some operations will return this if their inputs are out of range) INF_PLUS - Positive infinity, not really a number, but a valid input to and output of some functions. INF_MINUS - Negative infinity, not really a number, but a valid input to and output of some functions.

member.returns: e (the number for which the d/dx(e^x) = e^x)

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.Pow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Raises a number to an integer power (positive or negative). This is a very accurate and fast function, comparable to or faster than division (although it is slightly slower for negative powers, obviously)

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.Pow(BigNum.BigFloat)
member.summary: Raises to an aribitrary power. This is both slow (uses Log) and inaccurate. If you need to raise e^x use exp(). If you need an integer power, use the integer power function Pow(int) Accuracy Note: The function is only ever accurate to a maximum of 4 decimal digits For every 10x larger (or smaller) the power gets, you lose an additional decimal digit If you really need a precise result, do the calculation with an extra 32-bits and round Domain Note: This only works for powers of positive real numbers. Negative numbers will fail.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.Floor(BigNum.BigFloat)
member.summary: Returns the integer component of the input
member.param: The input number
member.remarks: The integer component returned will always be numerically closer to zero than the input: an input of -3.49 for instance would produce a value of 3.

member.summary: Two-variable iterative square root, taken from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methods_of_computing_square_roots#A_two-variable_iterative_method
member.remarks: This is quite a fast function, as elementary functions go. You can expect it to take about twice as long as a floating-point division.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.Log(BigNum.BigFloat)
member.summary: The natural logarithm, ln(x) (log base e)
member.remarks: This is a very slow function, despite repeated attempts at optimisation. To make it any faster, different strategies would be needed for integer operations. It does, however, scale well with the number of bits.
member.param: The number to find the natural logarithm of

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.Log10(BigNum.BigFloat)

member.remarks: This is a very slow function, despite repeated attempts at optimisation. To make it any faster, different strategies would be needed for integer operations. It does, however, scale well with the number of bits.
member.param: The number to find the base 10 logarithm of

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.Exp(BigNum.BigFloat)

The power to raise it to

member.summary: Raises to an aribitrary power. This is both slow (uses Log) and inaccurate. If you need to raise e^x use exp(). If you need an integer power, use the integer power function Pow(int)
member.remarks:
Accuracy Note: The function is only ever accurate to a maximum of 4 decimal digits For every 10x larger (or smaller) the power gets, you lose an additional decimal digit If you really need a precise result, do the calculation with an extra 32-bits and round
Domain Note: This only works for powers of positive real numbers. Negative numbers will fail.
member.param: The number to raise to a power
The power to raise it to

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.ToString

Returns a base-10 string representing the number.
Note: This is inefficient and possibly inaccurate. Please use with enough rounding digits (set using the RoundingDigits property) to ensure accuracy

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.Denormalise(System.Int32)
member.summary: Used for fixed point speed-ups (where the extra precision is not required). Note that Denormalised floats break the assumptions that underly Add() and Sub(), so they can only be used for multiplication

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.LogAGM1

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.CalculateLog2(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates ln(2) and returns -10^(n/2 + a bit) for reuse, using the AGM method as described in http://lacim.uqam.ca/~plouffe/articles/log2.pdf

member.name: M:BigNum.BigFloat.CalculatePi(System.Int32)

member.name: T:BigNum.BigInt
member.summary:
An arbitrary-precision integer class
Format: Each number consists of an array of 32-bit unsigned integers, and a bool sign value.
Applicability and Performance: This class is designed to be used for small extended precisions. It may not be safe (and certainly won't be fast) to use it with mixed-precision arguments. It does support, but will not be efficient for, numbers over around 2048 bits.
Notes: All conversions to and from strings are slow.
Conversions from simple integer types Int32, Int64, UInt32, UInt64 are performed using the appropriate constructor, and are relatively fast.
The class is written entirely in managed C# code, with not native or managed assembler. The use of native assembler would speed up the multiplication operations many times over, and therefore all higher-order operations too.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.#ctor(BigNum.PrecisionSpec)
member.summary: Constructs an empty BigInt to the desired precision.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a BigInt from a string, using the string length to determine the precision Note, operations on BigInts of non-matching precision are slow, so avoid using this constructor

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.#ctor(BigNum.BigInt,BigNum.PrecisionSpec,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructor for copying length and precision
member.param: The BigInt to copy
The precision of the new BigInt
decides whether to copy the actual input, or just its digit length

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.CastToPrecision(BigNum.BigInt,BigNum.PrecisionSpec)

member.summary: Squares the number.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.MulHi(BigNum.BigInt)
member.summary: Used for floating-point multiplication Stores the high bits of the multiplication only (the carry bit from the lower bits is missing, so the true answer might be 1 greater).

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.SquareHiFast(BigNum.BigInt)
member.summary: Floating-point helper function. Squares the number and keeps the high bits of the calculation. Takes a temporary BigInt as a working set.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.Div(BigNum.BigInt)
member.summary: This uses the schoolbook division algorithm, as decribed by http://www.treskal.com/kalle/exjobb/original-report.pdf Algorithms 3.1 (implemented by Div_31) and 3.2 (implemented by Div_32)

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.DivAndShift(BigNum.BigInt)
member.summary: This function is used for floating-point division.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.Mod(BigNum.BigInt)
member.summary: Calculates 'this' mod n2 (using the schoolbook division algorithm as above)

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.AddInternal(System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds a signed integer to the number.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.SubInternal(System.Int32)
member.summary: Subtract a signed integer from the number. This is internal because it will fail spectacularly if this number is negative or if n1 is bigger than this number.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.AddInternal(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Adds a signed integer to the number.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.SubInternal(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Internally subtracts a uint from the number (sign insensitive)

member.summary: Internal increment function (sign insensitive)

member.summary: Internal increment function (sign insensitive)

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.AddInternalBits(System.UInt32[])
member.summary: Used to add a digit array to a big int.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.AddInternal(BigNum.BigInt)
member.summary: Used to add with matching signs (true addition of the digit arrays) This is internal because it will fail spectacularly if n1 is negative.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.SubInternal(BigNum.BigInt)
member.summary: Used to subtract n1 (true subtraction of digit arrays) - n1 must be less than or equal to this number

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.GetRequiredDigitsForPrecision(BigNum.PrecisionSpec)
member.summary: Returns the length of the BigInt in 32-bit words for a given decimal precision

member.summary: Initialises the BigInt to a desired decimal precision

member.summary: Initialises the BigInt from a string, given a base and precision

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.IsTopBitOnlyBit
member.summary: Returns true if only the top bit is set: i.e. if the floating-point number is a power of 2

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.ZeroBitsHigh(System.Int32)
member.summary: Zeroes the n most significant bits of the number

member.summary: Zeroes the least-significant n bits.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.Zero
member.summary: Sets the number to 0

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.Round(System.Int32)
member.summary: Rounds off the least significant bits of the number. Can only round off up to 31 bits.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.AssignHigh(BigNum.BigInt)
member.summary: Used for casting between BigFloats of different precisions - this assumes that the number is a normalised mantissa.
member.returns: true if a round-up caused the high bits to become zero

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.SetHighDigits(System.Int64)
member.summary: Used for casting between long ints or doubles and floating-point numbers

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.SetHighDigit(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Used for casting between ints and doubles or floats.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.Pad
member.summary: Helper function for floating-point - extends the number to twice the precision and shifts the digits into the upper bits.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.Extend
member.summary: Helper function for floating-point - extends the number to twice the precision... This is a necessary step in floating-point division.

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.GetTopBit
member.summary: Gets the highest big of the integer (used for floating point stuff)

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.Normalise
member.summary: Used for floating point multiplication, this shifts the number so that the highest bit is set, and returns the number of places shifted.

member.param: the input to search for the MSB in

member.name: M:BigNum.BigInt.SetNumDigits(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the number of digits without changing the precision This method is made public only to facilitate fixed-point operations It should under no circumstances be used for anything else, because it breaks the BigNum(PrecisionSpec precision) constructor in dangerous and unpredictable ways.

member.summary: Cast to string
